reviewText: I'm a huge warhammer fan, but this one is sadly a miss. It's a clever concept, it's looking pretty and I really expected to love it. Voice acting is ok and story is fairly good for the part I have played. But the game is too random, chess and dice rolls really doesn't get along. It's not this kind of cool exciting randomness that leads to spectacular outcomes, rather the one that makes you feel cheated when you lose after playing your pieces right. There are many games that do randomness good, like Warhammer Armageddon or Warhammer Space Wolf, or Warhammer Quest or Warhammer Dark Omen. This just isn't one of them.

reviewText:
A Fair Review.
Wondering if you should grab this? Well heres a nice summary to help you decide if you want to or not.

What is this game? In a nutshell this game is chess with warhammer figures (but you can turn on the standard chess piece icon above their heads if you get confused) AND a chess LIKE game called regicide, but each piece has stats and abilities (which let you shoot, throw grenades,heal, shields, etc.) after youve made a standard chess move, (letting you alter the chess part greatly by killing pieces without making chess moves) which is cool to some and some hate it. I personally prefer standard chess, however regicide mode is fun and im glad they chose it for the single player campaign.

So this game is Chess with warhammer skins and an alternate chess-like game mode.

Overall the game has some pros and cons.

The pros

are that its chess with a warhammer skin and it looks very pretty both graphic and animation wise the sync kills are amazing when you take an enemy piece. It has a nice online community with match making, lobbies, ways to check stats, leveling up your army, the look of your soldiers, and even battle abilties to unlock for the regicide mode and entire army chapters for space marines, and clans for orks (so basically a different color scheme).

So the game works an runs very pretty and if you like chess its great. However...

The cons

are that there are some VERY infuriating bugs and even a design flaw or two. So the way you unlock stuff that was ALREADY IN THE GAME ready to go on release is done by either two ways, with real money cash shop (calm your p2w alarms) or you can unlock points per campaign mission, skirmish vs the ai, and mp matches. Sounds cool right? The problem is that right now you can easliy complete a mission and its secondary objectives and not get any points at all or credit, there have been MULTIPLE TIMES I have WON a mission and did not get credit for a the PRIMARY objective (aka winning the match!) or done the secondary objective MANY MANY MANY times and not gotten credit, since these points for completeing said things are used to purchase things that are also purchaseable with REAL money its like your being stolen from, and it happens WAY too often for them to not have noticed it. That does two things, leaves a REALLY bad taste in your mouth (unless you like seeing $ taken from you after you have earned it) and forces you to replay mission OVER AND OVER until you get credit which is annoying to say the least. Another HUGE gripe I have with this game and even consider a design flaw as other game give xp for hotseat matches, is that hotseat matches with friends gets you nothing! No cosmetic army experience or anything, this game was gifted to me because they new hotseat games were a HUGE thing at my house, and because of a few losers who might exploit it, we are being penalized and the only way to level up and make your army look cooler is to be forced to play against the AI or random people on the internet, call me crazy but I like social interation with the people I actually INTERACT with in real life, since this game doesn't seem to support that our hotseat game of choice will remain RISK II, or HOM&M # over this ANY DAY.

If you already know what regicide ( the game mode) is and its rules and like it's spin on chess and like playing chess vs ai oppenents or random people on the internet this game is for you and has potential, however if you had any hope of playing and earning rewards IN A GAME DESIGNED to be played by two people in chairs together (aka hotseat on a computer) you can't enjoy it with friends sadly as while the match may be fun, but the fact you didn't progress anything together instantly removes all fun in quite a demoralizing way. The game was gifted to me and I'm greatful for that, however I could not recommend this purchase until they fix the currency bugs, or enable cosmetics to be earned in hotseat.

Final Verdict:

All in all I'd wait for a discounted sale unless your friends list is packed with friends that own the game and youd want to play with because any form of chess against an AI is just really boring, and (to me) playing chess against random people is no where near as fun as friends on skype or heaven forbid in person.

If you plan on playing this by yourself and never hot-seat with anyone, the game is good and i'd normally recommend it, but I still won't recommend it until they fix the in-game currency bugs/ issues as they happen WAY too often, especially for content that was in the game at release. Once they fix those bugs I will change from negative to positive.

reviewText:
This game is aesthetically good with decent sound and models. The animations are good when it doesn't glitch.

The game was, however, not ready for release. The single player campaign is unplayable due to bad design, bugs, and serious lack of play-testing. Registration is forced to play online which is not a requirement listed on the store page. There was day 1 DLC skins in a game with only 2 playable races (fine for the price, but not with paid skins). Mechanically there are bugs all over the place (% hit is wildly broken). This game was not ready for release.

Worst and most offensive of all, the developers are simply deleting threads that are critical and point out shortcomings in the game trying to censor opinions. My refund request has been turned in at 2.2 hours. This review stands until then.

UPDATE 9/16/2015: I got my refund. A developer posted on this review asking for feedback. I found out that they did not delete the thread (although STEAM said it had been) as I thought and it was moved to the Feedback section. The last post there is from a different developer saying they are going to fix a couple of the issues but that other (I still think, bad) design decisions are/were intentional. I still don't recommend the game unless you're only interested in skirmish multiplayer, but I'm glad that they're still in active development.

reviewText:
First off, for anyone who reads this. This game is chess. Plainly chess. Chess with a warhammer 40k look and your chess pieces have abilities and guns. The campaign might differ a tad from normal chess. But everything else I've played is chess. Which kinda disappointed me because I expected more. I enjoy chess but I do not have to get into the detail and tactics of it. Thus I won't get that much better at it. Also if I ever play chess I play speed chess. I hoped this was something new I could pick up and start to learn from the ground up. But anyone who is good at chess will have a huge advantage.

The animations are cool but that's about it. I would guess that there is more to unlock if you play more of the game. But it's so slow paced that I could not stand playing 1 game of multiplayer less suffer through the campaign.

I was lost getting into it and even more lost getting out of it. If you like slow paced Chess then buy this. It's a interesting new spin on it. If you do not like chess. Then don't buy this.

reviewText:
This seems to be an attempt at blending Chess and Warhammer 40k, two great games, but in reality, it falls apart. The tutorial, which you can't skip, just points you to a bunch of confusing on-screen icons without explaining what they mean or what they do. When you finally get to play a game, you find that the rules of chess sometimes apply, but sometimes not - one of the biggest flaws is that putting the enemy leader into checkmate doesn't actually do anything - the Warboss, despite being in checkmate by a Terminator, was perfectly content to sit there, gunning down my Librarian and Assault Marine until I finally felled him with a sustained barrage of bolter fire.

Yes, the cathartic joy of perforating Orks with rocket-propelled rounds is obtainable here, and the graphics are excellent. But the voice acting is minimal - I think they have two, maybe three people doing all the voices. And since the actual rules of chess seem to be applied randomly here, anyone looking for that aforementioned cathartic joy is much better off with the many older 40k games available.

At least it's cheap.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have never reviewed a game before, however I made an exception here, I took the time to write this, to help prevent people making the mistake I made.

Firstly the game has chess at the core of the gameplay, with marines and orcs acting as reskinned chess pieces. Overall the kill animations and finishers are a spectacle, the first 10 times... After that I found myself skipping the limited number of animations to just save myself time, maybe I'm impatient? But seriously anyone who finds the same repetitve kill sequence entertaining, after a dozen times, might actually be the perfect target audience for the game, clearly i was not.

To sum up REGICIDE mode, it is chess, however while playing chess at the end of a 'movement phase' players can use abilities which impact their own, or the enemies pieces. For example using a shield on your own piece as defensive play, however the introduction of the ability to attack at distance (up to 4 tiles) and kill other pieces, TOTALLY RUINS THE GAME. I understand this steers it away from the normal rules of chess, but seriously any chess player who plays this game is going to flip out, after pieces which are perfectly SAFE, are removed from the board by some random pawn a few tiles away getting some lucky shot.

That is exactly the problem with REGICDE mode, it takes the game of chess which is a game of total skill with no RNG involved. To a game of well I might as well just charge my pieces forward since i can just shoot the guy

reviewText:
Amazing Promo eh ? That REALLY gets your attention ?

Then you find out its chess, but your pieces can actually shoot as well.

You get to move 1 piece per turn, limited to what the actual chess pieces would be able to move.

Followed by 3 actions points you can spend on shooting or healing your army.

From the promo i thought it was turn based mayhem on a battlefield, but in actuality its Warhammer 40k Battle chess.





I don't like the limited move ability of your troops, the starting positions of your army often block each others mooves so you have limited options and most games end up in 1 piece mooving 1 square each way then back while hoping you can shoot out your opponent, while your enemy always seems to have harder hitting weapons and more numbers.

Your troops have very short range they can actually shoot in, so often you find your self with a full army, but only 2 guys that actually have the range to fire.



If you can play chess, and you like the idea  that after each move you can bang off a few shots, this one is for YOU.

If you like your games with a bit more depth than a pretty, well animated battle chess, give it a miss.

Perhaps i should have read the rewiews before getting carried away with the opening vids eh.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I decided to update the review after such a long time and give it a try again.

The animations/kill moves are good looking so far.

A few battlefields.

2 Factions: Ork and Space Marine. Several additional skins for the space marines and orks. Some only unlockable through Xp or buying through the store.

Multiplayer.

There are two modes: Standard Chess and Regicide.


You now can choose,after unlocking, on a selection of skills (12 in total) that you can equip before the mission such as giving your units a one hit shield or a flag that boosts the damage of your space marines.

Chess: The Chess-AI now is pretty standard, after a few matches you can outsmart it (Yes, the AI till now does trivial bad chess-moves sometimes on normal, like sacrificing its own Queen etc.

Regicide: The AI does the same after full release, still sacrificing vital units,enabling you to move-kill its units. The AI doesn´t cover its own units like how it works in chess.


now...Singleplayer!
short transmissions of you as the commander and your loyal space marines what to do next. No cutscenes. As you start the game, you have a pre set of space marines, positioned pre set, with the goal to kill one or more ork, or to move in to a field. 10 Missions. Very short.

Still Not much variety, the AI is quick to beat (even on hard)

I have to say i still cant recommend it. You have to be a very hardcore wh40k fan thats drooling when space marines pass by.

For chess its too simple, for a game its without much content.

reviewText: SPACE MARINES TOO OVERPOWERED - I recommend this game if you only like Space Marines (unfortunately everybody only plays Space Marines). As an avid Ork player I'm extremely displeased at the modified version for their chess game. I'm glad it's in alpha because they need to make Orks stronger. In the past 2 games I've destroyed their queen, in my first game I had multiple pawns, and 4 special units left against 2 space marine pawns, a rook, and a king. Think you could win that right? If you're an Ork playing against a CPU you're always going to lose because Orks are severely underpowered when it comes to initiative. I've lost almost all my special units not to movement, but through initiative phase. Where as an Ork I only kill most units through movement and not initiative. I know Orks have sh**ty aim, but this is rediculous. Orks will always miss their shots, Space Marines will always hit and win their shots. Also another bug - SQUID BOMB DOES NOT WORK - I used it, and literally nothing happened. This is a good game if it's Space Marine VS. Space Marines or Orks vs. Orks but they need to balance it for different armies to fight - I like this game, but can't recommend just quite yet.

reviewText:
This is a Warhammer 40,000 version of chess with a few bells and whistles added. Let's see what it does right first:
PROS:
- Beautiful aesthetics. Seriously, this is a good looking game. The character models are well done, the animations are pretty damned good and the whole thing just looks great.
- Takes Chess and adds a few features to it. Oh, and adds an awesome Warhammer 40,000 skin to it.
- Allows you to play Marine vs Marine or Ork Vs Ork in addition to allowing you to fight against the opposite race.

CONS:
- The game is sluggish and slow. Seriously, most matches will take SEVERAL minutes. And that's because, while the animations DO look nice, they take for damn ever.
- The game's combat system is just damned dreadful. I'm sorry, but it is. The things they added to the Chess mechanics are neat, but most of them are damned worthless. Grenades are weak, attacks feel powerless and, while I get that this is chess, you REALLY don't want to get your big and beefy Warboss or Chapter Master upclose and personal or else you'll lose.
- The game looks great. It sounds terrible. The gun sounds are underwhelming, the explosions are very stock and run of the mill, the voice acting ranges from good to just god awful.
- This game, in its current state, costs more than I really deserves to.

That's my review. Please remember though, this game IS in early access. It is subject to change.
Total score: 4/10 - Poor.
